Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Flexible Multi-Scale Models of Transportation Network Service Recovery

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to transform emergency response planning for transportation service disruptions through the formulation and integration of hierarchical multi-scale models: (i) network optimization and expected covering models to evaluate strategies for allocating emergency responders across highway networks, and (ii) an economic interdependency model to optimize the multi-sector, multi-regional impacts of emergency response strategies on overarching productivity objectives. In the first tier of the modeling hierarchy, the PIs will formulate new transportation network optimization models to identify optimal configurations of emergency responders and dispatching protocols for resolving prioritized incidents based on utility and coverage metrics. In the second tier of the modeling hierarchy, the PIs will formulate an economic interdependency model to evaluate the efficacy of transportation network service strategies in minimizing congestion and higher-level objectives such as disruptions to workforce and commodity flows, economic loss, and sector inoperability.

If successful, the results of this research will enhance the capability of transportation planners and emergency managers through flexible models for deploying emergency responders to resolve varying incident priorities, as well as expanding the optimization focus to include large-scale interdependent impacts due to disruptions in workforce and commodity flows. This research will benefit society through an integrated framework for managing transportation resources from tactical (response) to strategic (multi-sector, multi-region impact) levels. The results have the potential to inform national guidelines for managing disruptions to critical interdependent infrastructure systems. Broader dissemination to the general public will be achieved via the creation of Internet-based research blogs and videos to explain the role of optimization, probability modeling, queuing, and regional economic analysis in modeling important service enterprise and public safety applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The transportation system, with the interconnected highway network being a primary focus of this work, is a critical infrastructure. Transportation network assets such as roads and bridges are vital to our economic well-being, safety, security, health, and way of life. For emergency response agencies, the transportation network also provides accessibility and mobility in response and recovery efforts. Disruptions in the highway network could incur widespread losses of functionality, whose congestion costs to users exceed $10B USD per year. This project studied how to effectively plan for the recovery from disruptions by designing models for deploying emergency responders to resolve varying incident priorities, while considering the interdependent economic impacts.


The research supported by this award was designed to study how to deploy emergency responders on a network to support decision-making that enhances public safety. Decisions in transportation applications are not made in isolation, because transportation systems are complex systems that operate in time and space. Every decision has the potential to affect other present and future decisions due to a number of factors such as congestion in the system, travel times, delays, and service unavailability. Understanding how to make interrelated and integrated decisions is necessary to achieve a good overall performance in the system. 


This research led to a deeper understanding of how to make interrelated and integrated transportation decisions by formulating, analyzing, and solving network optimization models. This research led the formulation of several new network optimization models that locate and deploy emergency responders on a network. By solving and analyzing these models, this research resulted in new insights into how to make integrated decisions to comprehensively improve the design and operation of emergency response systems.  This project also led to new analytical models for evaluating the design of public safety systems when the system is congested and when multiple vehicles respond to a single incident. A major contribution of the research was the derivation of new theoretical results that deepen our scientific understanding of how to make interrelated, sequential decisions in transportation systems. 


The results of this research led to important insights into the design and operation of emergency response systems to enhance public safety.  Research results were disseminated widely through peer-reviewed publications, conference talks, and research seminars. The research results were disseminated to public safety leaders and the general public through outreach lectures, media appearances, and social media.
